Given the full labeled dataset 𝒟f​u​l​l={𝒟f​e​d,𝒟Al​o​c}superscript𝒟𝑓𝑢𝑙𝑙superscript𝒟𝑓𝑒𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑙𝑜𝑐𝐴\mathcal{D}^{full}=\{\mathcal{D}^{fed},\mathcal{D}^{loc}_{A}\} composed by the overlapped part 𝒟f​e​d={𝒳Af​e​d,𝒴Af​e​d,𝒳Bf​e​d}superscript𝒟𝑓𝑒𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝒳𝑓𝑒𝑑𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝒴𝑓𝑒𝑑𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝒳𝑓𝑒𝑑𝐵\mathcal{D}^{fed}=\{\mathcal{X}^{fed}_{A},\mathcal{Y}^{fed}_{A},\mathcal{X}^{fed}_{B}\} and the non-overlapped part 𝒟Al​o​c={𝒳Al​o​c,𝒴Al​o​c}subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑙𝑜𝑐𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝒳𝑙𝑜𝑐𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝒴𝑙𝑜𝑐𝐴\mathcal{D}^{loc}_{A}=\{\mathcal{X}^{loc}_{A},\mathcal{Y}^{loc}_{A}\}, the aim of Semi-VFL is to learn a function s​(𝐱A)𝑠subscript𝐱𝐴s(\mathbf{x}_{A}) to model p​(y|𝐱A)𝑝conditional𝑦subscript𝐱𝐴p(y|\mathbf{x}_{A}) by fully utilizing 𝒟f​u​l​lsuperscript𝒟𝑓𝑢𝑙𝑙\mathcal{D}^{full}, where p​(y|𝐱A)𝑝conditional𝑦subscript𝐱𝐴p(y|\mathbf{x}_{A}) is the conditional label distribution regarding to the active party’s feature. The core goal of Semi-VFL is to achieve better results than No-VFL while relying only on active party features. Compared with traditional settings (as shown in table 1),
the advantages of Semi-VFL can be summarized as follow:

references: We use two well-known public CTR prediction datasets Criteo CriteoLabs (2014) and Avazu CriteoLabs (2014) to validate our method, and manually partition their attributes into two parts to simulate the vertical data setting. Details of datasets and the corresponding model structure are summarized in Table 2. The two partitioned field sets in each dataset are respectively called the “A” and the “B” by their natural order. It’s worth noting that, their contribution to label discrimination differs, so we alternatively select one of them as the active party (accompanied with the label) to validate JPL’s robustness against field importance.
